questions.text: According to the population strategy for prevention of cardiovascular disease, what is the recommended dietary allowance of cholesterol per day?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recommended dietary allowance of cholesterol per day by the American Heart Association is 100mg/ 1000 kcal.

  • Physiological Role of Cholesterol:
    • Cholesterol plays an essential role in the body, such as in cell membrane structure.
    • However, the liver produces enough cholesterol on its own, making dietary cholesterol largely unnecessary.
  • Cholesterol Target Levels:
    • A target average total cholesterol level of 190 mg/dL in adults over 18 years has been proposed as a realistic public health goal.
  • Evidence Linking Diet and Cardiovascular Risk:
    • Research consistently shows that higher dietary fat and cholesterol intake are associated with elevated blood cholesterol.
    • Elevated blood cholesterol, in turn, is strongly linked to increased cardiovascular disease risk.
  • American Heart Association (AHA) Dietary Guidelines:
    • The AHA advises individuals to limit dietary cholesterol to no more than 100 mg per 1,000 kcal consumed.
    • Regardless of calorie intake, cholesterol should not exceed 300 mg per day.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK235779/

choices.text: Make a surface running water source available
Add alum and lime to water

questions.text: A 50-year-old man from Chittoor, Andhra Pradesh, presents to the OPD with features of osteoporosis. Examination reveals outward bending of both legs. Which of the following is not used in his management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These signs, along with the location, suggest skeletal fluorosis resulting from excessive fluoride intake. Hence, fluoride supplementation is incorrect.

Role of Fluoride in the Body

  • 96% of fluoride in the human body is stored in bones and teeth.
  • Fluoride is essential for normal bone mineralization and dental enamel formation.
  • Fluoride is described as a "two-edged sword" due to its harmful effects in both excess and deficiency.

Fluoride in Drinking Water

  • Drinking water is the major source of fluoride for humans.
  • In most parts of India, the fluoride content in drinking water is about 0.5 mg/L.
  • In fluorosis-endemic areas, such as Chittoor, it may rise to 3-12 mg/L.
  • The recommended fluoride level in drinking water in India is 0.5 to 0.8 mg/L.

Fluoride Excess - Health Risks

  • Prolonged intake of excess fluoride leads to dental and skeletal fluorosis.
  • Skeletal fluorosis can mimic osteoporosis and cause bone deformities.
  • Management requires reducing fluoride intake.

Correct Management Approaches

  • Changing the Water Source:
    • One solution is to switch to a water source with lower fluoride content (ideal range: 0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). (Option C)
    • Running surface water (e.g., rivers) typically contains less fluoride than groundwater sources like wells. (Option B)
  • Chemical Treatment
    • If changing the source isn't feasible, chemical defluoridation can be done at a water treatment facility.
    • This method is moderately expensive.
    • The Nalgonda technique, developed by NEERI, Nagpur, is a chemical method to remove fluoride.
    • The technique involves the addition of two chemicals: lime and alum (in sequence). (Option D)
  • Other Preventive Measures
    • Fluoride supplements should not be given to children who already consume fluoridated water.
    • In areas with endemic fluorosis, fluoride toothpaste is not recommended for children under 6 years.

questions.text: Under Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation, what dose of iron and folic acid is given to girls 10-19 years of age:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The weekly iron and folic acid supplementation comes under the adolescent health programme, where a supervised weekly dose of 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid is provided on a fixed day to adolescents (10-19 years).

Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS):

Objective and Scope:

  • Launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Aims to address the high prevalence of anaemia among adolescent girls and boys.
  • Long-term goal: Break the intergenerational cycle of anaemia.
  • Short-term goal: Improve nutritional status and human capital.
  • Implemented in both rural and urban areas across the country.
  • Covers approximately 10.25 crore adolescents.

Key Interventions:

  • Weekly supplementation:
    • Supervised administration of iron and folic acid tablets.
    • Each tablet contains 100 mg elemental iron and 500 µg folic acid.
    • Administered on a fixed day each week.
  • Screening and Referral:
    • Adolescents are screened for moderate/severe anaemia.
    • Identified cases are referred to the appropriate health facilities.
  • De-worming:
    • Biannual administration of Albendazole 400 mg.
    • Given six months apart to control helminthic infections.
  • Information and Counselling:
    • Educate adolescents on improving dietary intake.
    • Promote actions to prevent intestinal worm infestation.

Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1024&lid=388

choices.text: Close all doors and windows and seal your home with plastic/tape
Open all windows and try to ventilate the house
Stay inside and wait for further instructions
Immediately run outside without checking the wind direction or alerts

questions.text: There is a report of toxic fumes leaking from a nearby chemical factory. What should be your immediate action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Before a Toxic Gas Emergency

  • Learn about local evacuation procedures and available shelters.
  • Get familiar with warning systems, such as sirens or public announcements.
  • Ensure doors and windows have secure, tight closures to prevent gas entry.
  • Prepare an emergency kit for the family, including essentials like water, food, medication, and first aid.

During a Toxic Gas Emergency

  • Avoid using telephones unless necessary to keep lines open for emergency services.
  • Stay tuned to updates and instructions via radio, television, or public loudspeakers.
  • Follow official directions immediately and carefully.
  • Secure your home by closing all doors and windows tightly. (Option B ruled out)
  • Block air vents and seal gaps or cracks using adhesive tape or plastic sheets.
  • Store clean water by filling bathtubs, buckets, or sinks.
  • Turn off all air-conditioning units, fans, and other ventilation systems to prevent fumes from entering.

After the Emergency Has Passed

  • Do not leave your shelter until authorities confirm it is safe to do so.
  • Follow all public health advice, including decontamination steps if you were exposed to the fumes.

questions.text: The interval between a host receiving an infection and the period of attaining maximum infectivity is called
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The interval between a host receiving an infection and the period of attaining maximum infectivity is called the generation time.

Generation Time

  • Definition: Generation time is the interval between a host's acquisition of infection and the point at which they are most infectious to others.
  • Relation to Incubation Period: (Option B)
    • Generally, generation time is roughly equal to the incubation period.
    • However, they are not identical.
    • Maximum infectivity may occur before or after the incubation period ends.
  • Example:
    • In mumps, individuals are most infectious about 48 hours before the appearance of swelling in the salivary glands.
  • Application in Transmission:
    • For person-to-person spread, the time between successive cases is influenced by the generation time.
    • The incubation period applies only to symptomatic infections (manifest disease).
    • Generation time applies to all transmissions, including both clinical and subclinical infections.

The communicable period (Option A) is defined as "the time during which an infectious agent may be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected person to another person, from an infected animal to man, or from an infected person to an animal, including arthropods."

The serial interval (Option D) is defined as "the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case."

questions.text:
In an experimental study, which of the following is the correct sequence of steps?
1. Randomisation
2. Manipulation
3. Statistical analysis
4. Follow-up (checked)
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basic Steps in Conducting an Experimental/ Randomised Control Study (RCT):

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental populations
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome

Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT):

  • Considered the gold standard for evaluating new programmes or therapies.
  • Ensures objective comparison between intervention and control groups.

questions.text: For a population of 70,00,000 with 30% of it belonging to the slum population, how many Urban PHCs are required for the slum population according to NUHM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to NUHM, 42 U-PHCs are required for this scenario.

  • According to NUHM guidelines, an Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC) is typically established for every 50,000-60,000 population.
  • When targeting slum areas specifically, one U-PHC is recommended for approximately 25,000-30,000 slum population.
  • In exceptional cases, such as highly dense or isolated slum clusters, one U-PHC may be set up for populations as low as 5,000-10,000.
  • In the given question, the total population is 70,00,000.
  • Out of this, 30% is the slum population, which means the slum population is 21,00,000 (30% of 70,00,000).
  • Using the standard norm of one U-PHC per 50,000 people, we divide the slum population by 50,000.
  • 21,00,000 ÷ 50,000 = 42
  • Therefore, to serve the slum population of this city, 42 Urban PHCs would be required.

choices.text: Place on the date of enumeration

questions.text: In a de facto census, individuals are counted based on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A de facto census is defined as counting individuals "where persons are found on census night" - that is, their physical location at the time of enumeration, regardless of where they usually live.

"Tabulations on a de facto basis use only (1) and (2) if all three types are present", where:

  • (1) = Always resident (present and usually lives there)
  • (2) = Temporarily visiting (present, but usually lives elsewhere)

This confirms that in a de facto census, people are counted based on where they are on the census date, even if that location is not their usual residence.

Place of birth (Option A): Place of birth may be collected as a demographic detail, but it is not the basis for census counting.

Place of employment (Option C): Employment location is used in labor or economic statistics, not in determining where someone is counted in a census.

Usual place of residence (Option D): This applies to the de jure method, not de facto. In a de jure census, persons are counted where they normally reside, even if they're absent on census night.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most appropriate to compare the mean hemoglobin levels between two independent groups?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In small samples, we account for sampling variation in standard deviations by using the t distribution in hypothesis testing. This is known as a t-test.
  • When comparing two independent groups, we use the unpaired t-test (also known as the independent samples t-test) because the groups are not related or matched.
  • This is in contrast to the paired t-test, which is used when the same subjects are measured twice (e.g., before and after an intervention) or when observations are naturally paired. (Option A)

ANOVA (Option C): Comparing means across three or more independent groups. There are only two groups in the question. While ANOVA can technically be used with two groups, it is unnecessary and less efficient than a t-test in that case.

Chi-square test (Option D): Used for comparing categorical variables (e.g., frequencies or proportions). Hemoglobin level is a continuous variable, not categorical. The chi-square test is not suitable for comparing means of continuous data.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with fever and dry cough was confirmed to have COVID-19. He was admitted to a district hospital and later died in the hospital. The death was registered 7 days later. What type of surveillance does this represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The type of surveillance is passive surveillance.

  • Passive surveillance is "a system by which a health jurisdiction receives reports submitted from hospitals, clinics, public health units, or other sources."
  • It is characterized by data being reported routinely, without active solicitation by public health authorities.
  • The patient was diagnosed and treated in a district hospital, and his death was later registered.
  • These reports are part of the routine information flow from healthcare facilities to public health authorities.
  • The death was registered 7 days later, reflecting the possible delay in data reporting.
  • This aligns with the source, which notes that passive surveillance has limited control over data quality and timeliness.

Active Surveillance (Option A): Involves proactive case-finding and is not applicable here.

Syndromic Surveillance (Option C): Focuses on pre-diagnostic symptom patterns; here, the case was already confirmed.

Sentinel Surveillance (Option D): Involves selected reporting sites — no such designation is mentioned for the hospital involved.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK11770/

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines will you use in your PHC?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vaccine vials 1 and 2 can be used as the Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVMs) indicate them as usable.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVMs) are chemical indicators that track cumulative heat exposure of vaccines throughout the supply chain.
  • Their primary purpose is to prevent administration of heat-damaged vaccines and to minimize unnecessary wastage by indicating whether a vaccine remains viable.
  • The vaccine manufacturer attaches a VVM to the vial, ampoule, or dropper.
  • It contains a color-changing inner square:
    • If the inner square becomes the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates excessive heat exposure, and the vaccine must be discarded.
    • The color change reflects cumulative exposure to heat, not just a single event.

Types of VVMs

  • There are four types of VVMs, classified based on the heat sensitivity of the vaccine:
    • VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30
    • The number refers to the number of days it takes the VVM to change color at a constant temperature of 37°C.
  • Vaccines with higher heat sensitivity use VVMs with lower numbers.

Uses and Benefits

  • VVMs help:
    • Ensure only potent vaccines are administered.
    • Identify which vials to use first (those with greater heat exposure).
    • Decide which vaccines to retain or discard during a cold chain break.
  • However, VVMs do not detect freezing exposure, which can also damage some vaccines.

questions.text: A mosquito larva is examined under a hand lens. It showed no siphon tube, abdominal palmate hairs are present, and the larvae rest parallel to the water surface. What is the likely mosquito species?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mosquito described here is the Anopheles mosquito.

questions.text: A study found that breast cancer screening increases the 5-year survival rate, but there is no change in overall mortality. What type of bias does this suggest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The bias observed here is lead-time bias.

  • Lead time bias occurs when earlier detection of a disease (such as through screening) gives the appearance of longer survival time, even though the actual course or outcome of the disease is unchanged.

When a disease is identified earlier, the time from diagnosis to death increases only because the clock started sooner-not because the patient lived longer.

  • In the given scenario, the screening appears to increase the 5-year survival rate.
  • However, overall mortality (total deaths due to the disease) remains the same, which indicates no real improvement in patient outcomes.
  • The benefit is only apparent, not real - patients still die at the same age or disease stage, but they are diagnosed earlier.
  • This gives a false sense of improved effectiveness of the screening.
  • The key indicator of lead time bias is improved survival metrics without an actual reduction in mortality, exactly as seen in this scenario.

Berksonian bias (Option A): Involves errors in hospital-based study populations, not related to the timing of diagnosis or survival measurement.

Survival bias (Option B): Occurs when individuals who don't survive long enough to be studied are excluded - not the case here.

Detection bias (Option D): Refers to differences in outcome detection due to group awareness, not applicable when the issue is the timing of detection vs actual outcome.

Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/lead-time-bias#

questions.text:
During a community medicine demonstration, medical students are instructed to perform the Nalgonda technique. Each student is asked to bring two material bags from the set shown below:
Bag A - Alum
Bag B - Gypsum
Bag C - Charcoal
Bag D - Lime
Which combination of bags is required to perform the Nalgonda technique correctly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These are the two materials - alum and lime - required for the Nalgonda technique as described in standard public health practice.

  • It is a chemical method developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI), Nagpur, for defluoridating drinking water.
  • The technique is used to reduce excessive fluoride in water supplies, especially in areas affected by endemic fluorosis.
  • Materials Used:
    • The process specifically involves the use of two key chemicals:
      • Alum (aluminium sulfate)
      • Lime (calcium hydroxide)
  • The technique involves the addition of alum and lime in sequence, followed by:
    • Flocculation (formation of clumps)
    • Sedimentation (settling of impurities)
    • Filtration (to obtain clean water)

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with bowing of the legs. Which of the following nutritional supplementation programs specifically covers children under 6 years of age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) covers children under 6 years of age.

Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Programme

  • Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) was launched in 1975 under the National Policy for Children.
  • The programme aims to improve the health, nutrition, and development of children and women.
  • It includes supplementary nutrition, vitamin A prophylaxis, and iron and folic acid distribution.
  • The beneficiaries are children below 6 years, adolescent girls aged 11 to 18 years, and pregnant and lactating mothers.
  • States and Union Territories are encouraged to expand ICDS projects in line with the Central pattern to cover a larger number of beneficiaries.
  • Services are delivered by Anganwadi Workers (AWWs) at the village level.
  • Each Anganwadi Centre covers a population of 400 to 800 people, while Mini Anganwadi Centres cover 150 to 400.
  • Mahila Mandals support Anganwadi Workers in delivering health and nutrition services.
  • Mukhyasevikas supervise the work of Anganwadi Workers.
  • Field-level supervision is done by the Child Development Project Officer (CDPO).

Mid-Day Meal Scheme (Option B): Targets school-going children (6-14 years) - does not include children under 6.

Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) (Option C): Focuses mainly on iron and folic acid supplementation, especially in adolescents, women, and school-age children, not specifically tailored for under-6 children.

National Nutrition Deficiency Control Programme (Option D): This is a general umbrella term and not a specific operational program like ICDS.

questions.text: A new community-level intervention is being evaluated. Researchers allocated 20 Primary Health Centres (PHCs) to receive standard care, and another 20 PHCs to receive the new community intervention. What is the most appropriate classification of this study?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A cluster randomized controlled trial (Cluster RCT) is a study design where groups of participants (referred to as clusters), rather than individuals, are randomly allocated to different interventions.
  • In the given case, the unit of randomization is the Primary Health Centres (PHCs), not individual participants.
  • A total of 40 PHCs were included: 20 received standard care, and 20 received the new community-level intervention.
  • This represents random allocation at the group level, fulfilling the criteria for a cluster RCT.
  • The design described aligns with the parallel cluster RCT model, where each cluster is assigned to a single intervention throughout the study period.

Statistical Considerations:

  • In cluster RCTs, statistical analysis must account for intra-cluster correlation, as individuals within a cluster may share similar characteristics or outcomes.

Quasi-experimental study (Option A): This design lacks randomization, which is not the case here.

Case-control study (Option C): This is a retrospective observational design comparing exposure histories of cases and controls. It does not involve interventions or randomization.

Cross-sectional (Option D) studies assess exposure and outcome at a single point in time. The study describes an intervention and follow-up, which implies a longitudinal component, not a one-time snapshot.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8277254/

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate method used in health planning to assess whether objectives and targets are being fulfilled and to evaluate the quality of outcomes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In health planning, evaluation is the most appropriate method used to assess whether objectives and targets are being fulfilled and to evaluate the quality of outcomes.

Steps of health planning include:

  • Analysis of the health situation
  • Establishment of objectives and goals
  • Assessment of resources
  • Fixing priorities
  • Write-up formulated plan
  • Programming and implementation
  • Monitoring
  • Evaluation

Evaluation

  • Evaluation focuses on assessing the achievement of the stated goals and objectives of a program.
  • It goes beyond just tracking progress (which is what monitoring does) and looks at:
    • Outcome effectiveness: Were the goals reached?
    • Efficiency: Were resources used wisely?
    • Adequacy: Was the program sufficient to meet the needs?
    • Acceptance: Was it well-received by those involved?
  • As cited from the WHO Expert Committee, evaluation:
    • Measures the degree to which objectives and targets are fulfilled.
    • Assesses the quality of the results.
    • Evaluates the productivity of the resources used.
    • Analyzes cost-effectiveness.
    • Guides reallocation of priorities and resources based on updated needs.

Supervision (Option A) ensures activities are carried out correctly, often involving guidance and support.

Monitoring (Option B) checks ongoing activities - it's day-to-day and operational.

Planning (Option D) is about formulating objectives and deciding how to reach them.

choices.text: ½ to 1 khatori, 3 times per day
½ to 1 khatori, 4 times per day
½ to 1 khatori, 5 times per day
½ to 1 khatori, 6 times per day

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is on complementary feeding along with continued breastfeeding. The child is given a khatori of semi-solid millet food. What is the recommended frequency and amount per day?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Complementary feed is started with 2-3 spoons up to 1/2 katori, given 2 to 3 times a day.

Reference: https://www.nhm.gov.in/MAA/One_Day_Sensitization_Module/One_Day_Sensitization_Module_English_lowres.pdf
